chapters.chapterTitle: Elijah Taken Up; Elisha Succeeds Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 2:1-12 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Elijah and Elisha and the dramatic events of the Jordan crossing.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I will not leave you' (v. 2) - Elisha's refusal to stay behind
Pay attention to Elijah's final words: 'You have asked a hard thing' (v. 10) and the immediate response of Elisha's cry (v. 11)
The repeated phrase 'the LORD' (v. 10, 11) shows Elisha's knowledge of God's action

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (Elijah, Elisha, the prophets) does WHAT (Elijah is taken up, Elisha inherits the mantle) WHERE (Bethel, Jordan) and WHY (Elijah's ascension and Elisha's inheritance).
tips: Include Elisha's refusal to stay behind at Bethel (v. 2)
Note the Jordan crossing where Elijah parts the water (v. 4)
Describe Elisha's immediate response to Elijah's ascension (v. 11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elisha's refusal to stay behind (v. 2), the Jordan crossing (v. 4-5), or Elisha's cry when Elijah is taken (v. 11).
tips: Elisha's declaration 'I will not leave you' shows deep commitment to Elijah
The water parting in the Jordan is a powerful sign of God's power
Elisha's cry: 'My father, my father! The chariots of Israel and its horsemen!' (v. 11) is emotionally intense and shows his distress

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the editors of 2 Kings trying to communicate to exilic Israel about Elijah's ascension and Elisha's inheritance?
tips: This passage shows that God's prophetic line continues through faithful disciples (Elisha), which is crucial for exiles who have lost their prophets
The double portion of the spirit (v. 15) foreshadows the outpouring of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost
The event demonstrates that God's power is not dependent on human status but on faithfulness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of the 'sons of the prophets', the meaning of 'double portion', and the sudden ascension.
tips: The 'sons of the prophets' (v. 2) are a group of prophets who were likely part of Elijah's circle, but their role here is to test Elisha's knowledge
A 'double portion of your spirit' (v. 15) refers to the full inheritance of prophetic power, not a physical double
The chariot of fire and horses of fire (v. 11) is a divine manifestation that separates Elijah from Elisha, showing the divine nature of the event

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Elisha inherits the mantle of prophecy. What area of your life requires you to take on a new responsibility with the 'double portion' of God's spirit this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel you are not being used by God
Think about how you can serve others with the authority and power that comes from God
Practice being a 'spiritual leader' in your small group or family

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the gift of the 'double portion' of God's spirit to empower you to be a faithful leader and to follow the path of Elijah's example.
tips: Ask God to give you the courage to take on new responsibilities
Pray that you will be ready to face the 'chariots of fire' when circumstances become difficult
Thank God that He provides a new leader when the old one goes

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 7:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the prophecy in verses 1-2, the lepers' despair in verse 3, and their guilt in verse 7.
tips: Notice the phrase 'a seah of fine flour will sell for a shekel' (v.1) which is the economic prophecy
Pay attention to the lepers' urgent decision: 'why sit here until we die?' (v.3)
Listen for the repetition of 'this is not right' (v.7) when they feel guilt

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize who, what, where, and why in 2 Kings 7:1-20.
tips: Include the four lepers outside the gate
Note the specific prophecy about flour and barley prices
Describe their action of plundering the empty camp and subsequent guilt

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elisha's prophecy (v.1-2), the lepers' decision to surrender (v.3), or their guilt (v.7)?
tips: The lepers' immediate action to go to the Syrian camp at twilight (v.4) shows urgency and faith
The phrase 'this is not rightâ€”we have good news but keep silent' (v.7) is a powerful moment of realization
The crowd trampling the captain (v.18-20) demonstrates the consequence of scoffing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Jeremiah/editors) trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage about the siege being lifted?
tips: This passage shows that God's provision is real and must be shared (like the lepers who had the news but didn't act)
The lepers' silence was a warning that exilic Israel might be ignoring God's provision in their own circumstances
The captain's death is a sign that rejecting God's provision leads to destruction

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The lepers' condition, the prophecy's meaning, or the Syrians' flight?
tips: Lepers were considered unclean and excluded from society (Leviticus 13), so they were outside the gate but still in the city
The prophecy uses ancient units: 1 seah of flour = about 20 liters, 1 shekel = a small amount of silver; the price being fixed shows economic recovery
The Syrians fled because they thought Israel had hired Hittites and Egyptians (a common military alliance) but the LORD made them hear a false alarm

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, share the good news you have with someone who is struggling, just as the lepers shared the news of the empty camp.
tips: Think about a person who is in need or despair
Consider how you can share the hope of God's provision without judgment
Practice sharing the good news in a way that is both practical and sensitive

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for providing and ask for courage to share the good news.
tips: Thank God for the provision of the empty camp and the opportunity to share the good news
Pray for the courage to speak the gospel without fear
Ask God to help you not remain silent when you have good news

chapters.chapterTitle: Athaliah Usurps; Joash Preserved and Crowned

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 11:1-21 aloud, focusing on the tension between Athaliah's power and the hidden king.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'treason' (v.10) as Athaliah's reaction
Pay attention to the phrase 'David's spears and shields' (v.11) from the temple
The emotional shift from Athaliah's rage to the people's joy in v.12-13

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Athaliah, Jehoiada, Joash), what (the coup and preservation of the Davidic line), where (the temple and palace), and why (to prevent the destruction of the Davidic line).
tips: Include the six-year hiding of Joash in the temple
Note Jehoiada's role as priest and leader of the coup
Mention the destruction of Baal worship and the killing of the priest of Baal

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the hidden king (v.3-4), Jehoiada's coup (v.11-12), or the immediate aftermath (v.18-21).
tips: The phrase 'the LORD's people' (v.19) shows a new covenant identity
The destruction of Baal's house (v.20) symbolizes the end of idolatry
The king's anointing (v.12) and immediate coronation (v.13) highlight God's direct involvement

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel about God preserving the Davidic line after the temple's destruction?
tips: This passage reassures exiles that God's promise to David (2 Samuel 7) remains active
The hidden king foreshadows Christ being born in the temple (Matthew 2:1-6)
Jehoiada's covenant (v.19) shows God's people will be renewed through the Davidic line

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The role of 'Carites' (v.11), the meaning of 'David's spears and shields' (v.11), or the immediate execution of Athaliah (v.10)?
tips: 'Carites' (or 'the army of the LORD') likely refers to the temple guards or loyalists
David's spears and shields are from the temple's military equipment, showing the king's protection
Athaliah's death is swift and brutal to prevent further idolatry

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a 'Jehoiada' in your life to preserve the Davidic line of God's kingdom? What specific action can you take this week to protect the vulnerable?
tips: Identify one person in your life who needs protection (like the hidden king)
Pray for courage to act like Jehoiada when the church is in danger
Commit to one act of protection for the vulnerable this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray that God would preserve His people from the destruction of the Davidic line in your life.
tips: Thank God for preserving the true king in the temple (Joash) despite the chaos
Pray for the strength to be a protector of the vulnerable
Ask God to remove the 'Athaliah' in your life who seeks to destroy the true king

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 12:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Joash and Jehoiada in verses 4-6 and the emotional tone of the priests' failure in verses 4-5.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the house' (temple) appears 5 times in this chapter (v.4, 6, 7, 8, 13)
Pay attention to the contrast between the priests' initial failure and the honest work of the repairers (v.13-14)
The abrupt ending with Joash's death at Beth-millo (v.25) creates a sense of tragedy

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Joash, priests, Jehoiada) does WHAT (repairs the temple, collects money for repairs) WHERE (Jerusalem) and WHY (to maintain the temple and avoid sin).
tips: Include Joash ordering the priests to collect temple money for repairs (v.4)
Note the priests' failure to repair by the 23rd year (v.4)
Jehoiada's solution: a chest beside the altar for offerings (v.13-14)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the chest solution (v.13-14), the honest workmen (v.14), or Joash's sacrifice of treasures (v.16).
tips: The chest solution is a practical, honest system that avoids corruption (v.13-14)
The workmen are described as 'honest' and don't demand accounting (v.14) - a model of transparent work
Joash's sacrifice of treasures to buy off Hazael (v.16) shows his willingness to protect Jerusalem despite the cost

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage?
tips: Consider the context of exilic Israel: the temple was a symbol of God's presence and the need for proper maintenance
The passage shows that even when leaders are obedient, systemic issues (like corruption) must be addressed with transparent solutions
The temple repair story foreshadows the need for the true temple (Christ) to be maintained by the community of faith

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the priests, the meaning of 'high places', or Joash's assassination?
tips: 'High places' (v.1) refers to places of pagan worship outside the temple, which were common in Canaan but forbidden by God
The chest solution (v.13) might seem odd because it's a new method for collecting offerings, but it ensures the money goes directly to repairs without corruption
The assassination of Joash (v.25) is sudden and raises questions about the political instability in Jerusalem

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to a specific theme from this passage: the honest work of the repairers. What can you do this week to be a 'honest' worker in your community or church?
tips: Think about a situation where you have to handle resources without corruption
How can you be transparent in your work or finances?
Practice accountability by sharing your work with others (like the workmen who didn't demand accounting)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of honest work and the need for the temple (community) to be maintained.
tips: Thank God for the honest workmen in the temple repair (v.14)
Pray for the church to be transparent in its finances and leadership
Ask for courage to be a repairer in your community when things are broken

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 13:1-25 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Jehoash and Elisha in verses 14-15 and the resurrection event in verses 20-21.
tips: Note the emotional tone of Jehoash weeping: 'my father, my father!' (v.14)
Pay attention to Elisha's final instruction: 'shoot east' (v.15)
The phrase 'the LORD's arrow of victory' in v.15

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Jehoahaz and Jehoash) does WHAT (reign over Israel, follow evil, fight Syria), WHERE (in Israel), and WHY (to follow Jeroboam's sins and the Asherah).
tips: Include the reduction of Jehoahaz's army to 50 horsemen, 10 chariots, and 10,000 infantry (v.13)
Note Elisha's death and the resurrection of the man from Elisha's tomb (v.20-21)
Jehoash takes back cities from Ben-hadad three times (v.25)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Elisha's final prophecy (v.15-17), the resurrection of the man (v.20-21), or Jehoash's weeping (v.14).
tips: Elisha's instruction to shoot the arrows: 'strike Syria at Aphek until you destroy them' (v.15) - shows God's decisive action against Syria
The man reviving by touching Elisha's bones (v.20-21) - a powerful sign of resurrection power
Jehoash's emotional response: 'my father, my father!' (v.14) - shows the depth of his grief and respect for Elisha

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Jeremiah/editors) trying to communicate to exilic Israel about God's faithfulness and deliverance through Elisha?
tips: Exilic Israel needed hope that God would provide a savior (like Elisha) to deliver them from their enemies
The resurrection of the man at Elisha's tomb foreshadows Christ's resurrection power
God's grace to Israel for the sake of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (v.17) reassures them of God's covenant faithfulness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of Elisha in the final events, the meaning of the arrow prophecy, or the resurrection of the man.
tips: The phrase 'the LORD's arrow of victory' (v.15) might seem metaphorical but refers to God's decisive military action against Syria
The resurrection of the man by touching Elisha's bones (v.20-21) is a sign of God's power that is more than physical but spiritual
The historical context of Syria oppressing Israel (Hazael and Ben-hadad) is complex because exiles in Babylon might not have known the current conflicts

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can the theme of resurrection power (from Elisha's bones) be applied to your life this week?
tips: Consider a time when you felt 'dead' in your faith but God has given you new life (like the man who revived)
Pray for the power of Christ's resurrection to touch your life when you face trials
Actively seek to 'touch' God's provision in your life through faith, just as the man touched Elisha's bones

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's resurrection power to transform your life and the life of your community.
tips: Thank God for the resurrection power that brings life to all who touch Him by faith (as in Elisha's bones)
Ask for the courage to trust God's provision in difficult circumstances, just as Jehoash trusted Elisha's prophecy
Pray for the church to experience resurrection power in the context of current conflicts

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 14:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Amaziah and Jehoash in verses 12-14 and the description of Jerusalem's wall being broken in verse 15.
tips: Note the repetition of 'the LORD' in the context of Amaziah's faith
Pay attention to the phrase 'the wall of Jerusalem' in verse 15, which symbolizes the city's vulnerability
Observe the emotional shift from Amaziah's pride to his defeat in verses 12-14

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who (Amaziah, Jehoash, Jeroboam II), what (events of conquest and defeat), where (Judah, Israel, Jerusalem), when (during the reigns of Amaziah and Jeroboam II), and why (to show the consequences of pride and the LORD's sovereignty).
tips: Include Amaziah's victory over Edom and taking Sela (v. 6-7)
Note Jehoash's response to Amaziah's challenge with the parable (v. 12-14)
Mention the aftermath: Amaziah's defeat, Jerusalem's wall broken, and Jeroboam II's restoration of territory (v. 20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Amaziah's pride (v. 10-11), Jehoash's parable (v. 12-14), or the restoration of Israel's territory by Jeroboam II (v. 20).
tips: The parable in verses 12-14 is a powerful metaphor showing that Amaziah's victory over Edom was temporary and his pride would lead to downfall
The restoration of territory by Jeroboam II (v. 20) shows God's faithfulness despite Israel's wickedness
The phrase 'the LORD has not said He would blot out Israel's name' (v. 20) is a profound promise of God's preservation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Jeremiah/editors) trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage about Amaziah and Jeroboam II?
tips: The passage reassures exilic Israel that God's promise to preserve His people (Israel) remains even when they are disobedient
It shows that God uses even wicked rulers to accomplish His purposes (e.g., Jeroboam II restoring territory)
This passage emphasizes that God's sovereignty and faithfulness are not dependent on human righteousness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The parable of Jehoash (v. 12-14), the meaning of 'Sela', or the historical context of the Edomites and Israelites.
tips: The parable in verse 12-14 uses a thistle and cedar to illustrate that Amaziah's victory over Edom was not a sign of God's favor but a temporary triumph
Sela (v. 7) is a strategic location in the desert that Amaziah took, which was important for controlling trade routes
The phrase 'the LORD has not said He would blot out Israel's name' (v. 20) is a direct reference to God's covenant promises and the fact that Israel would not be destroyed despite their sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can we apply the lesson of pride leading to defeat (from Amaziah's story) to our current lives?
tips: When you feel proud after a small victory, ask: 'Is this a temporary triumph or a sign of God's favor?'
Pray for humility after a win, especially when it seems like you've done something great
Remember that God's true victory is in His sovereignty, not in human achievements

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for humility and trust in God's sovereignty, especially when you feel successful.
tips: Ask God to help you recognize that your victories are temporary
Pray that you would not let pride lead you to ignore God's warnings
Thank God for His promise that He will not destroy His people despite their wickedness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 15:1-20 aloud, focusing on the rapid succession of kings and the leprosy incident.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'doing evil' (v.1, v.3, v.4, v.6, v.14, v.15, v.17, v.19)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the leprosy (v.5) and the violence (v.21-22)
Listen for the pattern of short reigns and violence in Israel (v.21-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Azariah (Uzziah) becoming king at 16 and his leprosy (v.1-5)
Note the rapid succession in Israel: Zechariah (6 months), Shallum (1 month), Menahem (10 years), Pekahiah (2 years), Pekah (20 years), and Hoshea (killing Pekah)
Explain the consequence: Assyrian invasion and deportation (v.19-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Azariah's leprosy (v.5), the rapid succession in Israel (v.21-22), or the Assyrian payment (v.19).
tips: Azariah's leprosy is a sign of divine judgment that he must live in isolation (v.5) - it shows that even a righteous king (who did right like his father) cannot avoid God's wrath for idolatry
The rapid succession of kings in Israel (v.21-22) is shocking: four kings in a short time, each killing the previous one
The payment of 1,000 talents of silver to Assyria (v.19) reveals the depth of Israel's desperation and the cost of survival

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage?
tips: The passage warns that unrighteous rulers and idolatry (high places) lead to violent instability and divine judgment
It points to the coming Assyrian invasion as a direct consequence of Israel's sin
The theme of Christ's kingdom (eternal stability) contrasts with the temporary, violent rule of these kings

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'high places', the leprosy as divine judgment, and the rapid succession of kings.
tips: 'High places' (v.3) refer to places of idolatrous worship in ancient Israel, not just any elevated location
Leprosy in this context is a spiritual condition (divine punishment) rather than the physical disease we know today
The rapid succession of kings in Israel (v.21-22) is a historical pattern of violence and instability that was common in the northern kingdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of rapid succession and violence in the kingdom apply to your life this week?
tips: Consider how your actions might lead to instability in your relationships or community
Ask God to help you avoid the cycle of violence by choosing reconciliation and justice
Pray for wisdom to make decisions that promote long-term stability (like avoiding idolatry in your life)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of instability and violence in the kingdom.
tips: Thank God for His judgment on unrighteous rulers and for His promise of a stable kingdom through Christ
Ask for courage to break the cycle of violence in your family or community
Pray for the strength to choose right relationships and avoid idolatry in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 16:1-23 aloud, focusing on the dialogue with Assyria and the temple alterations.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I am your servant and son' (v.13) shows Ahaz's plea for Assyrian help
Emphasize the repeated phrase 'high places' (v.11) indicating idolatry
The emotional shift in Ahaz's actions: from temple defacing to the new altar (v.17-20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Ahaz) did what (sought Assyrian help, defaced the temple), where (Judah and Damascus), and why (to avoid destruction from Syria and Israel).
tips: Ahaz's child sacrifice (v.3) and idolatry (v.11)
The Assyrian appeal (v.13) and the temple defacing (v.17-20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Ahaz's plea to Assyria (v.13), the altar design from Damascus (v.18), or the temple alterations (v.20).
tips: Ahaz's desperate plea: 'I am your servant and son' shows his complete abandonment of God for human power
The altar design from Damascus (v.18) is a direct pagan influence on the temple
The defacing of the temple (v.20) is a shocking act of idolatry that shows the depth of his sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was the author (Jeremiah/editors) trying to communicate to exilic Israel about God's sovereignty and the danger of relying on human alliances?
tips: The passage warns against seeking military or political power from foreign empires (like Assyria) instead of God
It emphasizes that God alone is the true provider of salvation and protection
This serves as a warning to exilic Israel that they must not follow the patterns of Ahaz's idolatry and political weakness

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The child sacrifice, why Ahaz sent for Assyria, and the temple alterations.
tips: Child sacrifice in Canaan was common (v.3), but God forbids it (Exodus 22:21) - Ahaz is following Canaanite practices
Ahaz's appeal to Assyria (v.13) is a political move to avoid destruction, but it shows his spiritual blindness
The temple alterations (v.20) involve removing the bronze sea (a symbol of God's presence) and changing the entrance - a sign of idolatry and defilement

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid relying on human alliances or political power for your salvation this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you might be seeking help from a person or group instead of God
Practice surrendering a specific area (like finances or relationships) to God's provision
Remind yourself that only Christ (not political power) can save you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He provides salvation through Christ, not human alliances.
tips: Thank God for the promise that Christ alone is the true salvation
Pray for strength to resist idolatry and seek God's guidance
Ask God to help you trust Him in difficult circumstances

questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 19:1-37 aloud, paying attention to the emotional shift from Hezekiah's fear to his prayer (v. 11-12) and the angelic intervention (v. 35-37).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' in Hezekiah's prayer (v. 12-13) and in Isaiah's response (v. 23-24)
Pay attention to the phrase 'virgin daughter of Zion' (v. 7) which emphasizes God's unique protection of Jerusalem

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Hezekiah, Sennacherib, Isaiah, Rabshakeh) does WHAT (Hezekiah prays, Isaiah delivers the oracle, Sennacherib sends messengers) WHERE (Jerusalem and Assyria) and WHY (to respond to the Assyrian threat and assert God's sovereignty).
tips: Include Hezekiah's tearful response to the Assyrian threat (v. 1-11)
Note the role of the Assyrian messenger (Rabshakeh) and the Assyrian army (v. 1-10)
Describe the angelic strike and the death of Sennacherib (v. 35-37)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Hezekiah's prayer (v. 12-13), the angelic strike (v. 35-37), or the sign about the crops (v. 33-34)?
tips: Hezekiah's prayer is a powerful example of confessing God's uniqueness in the face of Assyrian might
The angelic strike of 185,000 is a dramatic demonstration of God's power that the Assyrians could not counter
The sign about the crops (eating what grows of itself) is a practical hope for the future

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What were the editors of 2 Kings trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage reassures exiles that God is sovereign over even the most powerful nations and will protect His people
It emphasizes the importance of trusting God's promises in the face of overwhelming threats
The passage shows that God's power is not tied to military might but to His character and covenant

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the angel in killing Assyrians? Why did Sennacherib send messengers? What does 'virgin daughter of Zion' mean?
tips: The angelic strike (v. 35) is a unique event in the Bible; it shows God's direct intervention without a human agent
The Assyrian army was a common threat to Israel, but Sennacherib's specific threat (Rabshakeh) was a political maneuver to intimidate
'Virgin daughter of Zion' (v. 7) is a poetic way to refer to Jerusalem, emphasizing God's protection of the city

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Hezekiah's prayer of confession and trust. What situation requires you to confess God's uniqueness and trust His provision this week?
tips: Consider a time when you've been tempted to trust a false god (e.g., worldly success) and have to confess that only God is sovereign
Pray for the courage to speak truth about God's sovereignty in your current struggles

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His sovereignty and power. Ask for courage to trust Him in the face of overwhelming threats.
tips: Thank God for the protection of His people through the angelic strike
Pray for the strength to resist the temptation to rely on human power rather than God
Ask for the remnant of faith to emerge in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 21:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the description of Manasseh's wickedness and the LORD's judgment.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'he did evil' to emphasize the depth of sin
Pay attention to the emotional weight of 'wiped as a dish' and 'innocent blood'
Listen for the contrast between Manasseh's actions and the LORD's response

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Manasseh and his son Amon), WHAT (the wicked acts and the judgment), WHERE (Jerusalem), and WHY (to show the consequences of idolatry).
tips: Include the rebuilding of high places and altars to Baal
Note the shedding of innocent blood
Describe the LORD's judgment: Jerusalem being wiped as a dish

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the bloodshed (v.10), the rebuilding of high places (v.3), or the LORD's declaration that Manasseh has done more evil than the Amorites (v.13)?
tips: The phrase 'wiped as a dish' (v.13) is shocking and vivid, showing complete destruction
The bloodshed (v.10) is a powerful image of the cost of idolatry and injustice
The comparison to the Amorites (v.13) emphasizes the severity of Manasseh's sin

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel about the consequences of idolatry and the need for repentance?
tips: The passage warns that continued idolatry leads to national destruction and exile
It points to the hope in Christ's blood that provides forgiveness
The judgment is a call to repentance before it's too late

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The extent of Manasseh's wickedness? Why the bloodshed? What does 'wiped as a dish' mean?
tips: The term 'innocent blood' refers to the blood of children and the innocent killed for idolatrous purposes
'Wiped as a dish' is a metaphor for complete destruction
The phrase 'more evil than the Amorites' compares Manasseh's sin to the worst nations God had previously driven out

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of innocent blood (v.10) challenge us to avoid injustice and protect the vulnerable this week?
tips: Consider an instance where you have been part of a situation that caused harm to the innocent
Pray for the courage to speak up for the oppressed
Take one concrete step to ensure your actions do not lead to the shedding of innocent blood

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of innocent blood and the LORD's judgment.
tips: Thank God that He sees the blood of the innocent and is just
Ask for the strength to avoid taking innocent blood in your actions
Pray for the remnant of Judah to turn to the LORD and avoid the judgment described

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 23:1-25 aloud, focusing on the sequence of reforms and the tragic end.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' in the covenant (v.3) and the removal of idolatry (v.5)
Pay attention to the phrase 'defiled' used for Topheth (v.6) and the Bethel altar (v.12)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Josiah) does WHAT (reforms and death), WHERE (in Judah), and WHY (to return to God's covenant).
tips: Include the reading of the Book of the Covenant (v.3-5) and the defiling of the Bethel altar (v.12-13)
Note the Passover as the greatest since the judges' days (v.21)
Mention Josiah's death at Megiddo (v.29-30)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the defiling of the Bethel altar (v.12-13) as a prophesied fulfillment, the Passover (v.21), or Josiah's death (v.29-30).
tips: The Bethel altar defilement fulfills a prophecy from 1 Kings 13, showing God's faithfulness
The Passover in the temple is described as the greatest since the judges' days, emphasizing renewal
Josiah's death at Megiddo (v.29-30) is a tragic end to a great reformer

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel about God's covenant and the cost of obedience?
tips: The passage shows that God's covenant is central and requires comprehensive obedience
It warns that even great reforms cannot avoid the consequences of sin (Josiah's death)
It points to the need for a renewed heart, not just ritual changes

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The defiling of Topheth (v.6), the Bethel altar defilement (v.12-13), or the Passover (v.21).
tips: Topheth was a place for child sacrifice (as in Jeremiah 7:31), so defiling it means preventing this practice
The Bethel altar defilement was a fulfillment of a prophecy from 1 Kings 13, which shows God's faithfulness to His word
The Passover being the greatest since the judges' days (v.21) refers to the purity of the ritual and the people's commitment

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you follow Josiah's example of comprehensive obedience in your life this week?
tips: Choose one area where you can remove idolatry (e.g., a habit that distracts you from God)
Commit to a weekly act of obedience like Josiah did (e.g., reading the Book of the Covenant in your heart)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for courage to obey God's commands, like Josiah, and for the protection of the covenant community.
tips: Ask God to help you see the cost of disobedience in your life
Pray for a renewed heart that seeks God's covenant
Thank God for the prophecy fulfillment and the Passover that points to Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 24:1-17 aloud, paying attention to the emotional weight of Jehoiachin's surrender (verse 13) and the description of the deportation (verses 14-15).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Jehoiachin' and 'Jehoiakim' to show the line of kings
Pay attention to the phrase 'the LORD sends' (verse 10) indicating divine judgment
Emphasize the emotional impact of the surrender in verse 13

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved (the kings of Judah and Babylon), WHAT happens (the rebellion and exile), WHERE (in Jerusalem), WHEN (during Jehoiachin's short reign), and WHY (the sins of the nation leading to divine judgment).
tips: Include the three-month reign of Jehoiachin and his surrender to Babylon
Note the deportation of 10,000 people and the destruction of temple treasures
Mention the renaming of Mattaniah to Zedekiah (v.17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the immediate surrender of Jehoiachin (verse 13), the detail of the deportation (verses 14-15), or the renaming of Mattaniah to Zedekiah (verse 17)?
tips: Jehoiachin's surrender without resistance shows the depth of the nation's sin and the completeness of the judgment
The specific count of 10,000 deportees (verse 14) emphasizes the scale of the disaster
The renaming of Mattaniah to Zedekiah (verse 17) symbolizes the new, puppet king under Babylonian control

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage about their present situation and future hope?
tips: This passage shows that the sin of the nation (especially the bloodshed and idolatry) has led to the destruction of the temple and the exile, but it also points to the future restoration through the L
The Christ connection: the temple treasures being carried to Babylon foreshadows the ultimate destruction of the temple (the body of Christ) but also the promise of restoration

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The sequence of kings, the role of Egypt vs. Babylon, or the meaning of the deportation?
tips: The timeline of kings (Jehoahaz, Jehoiakim, Jehoiachin) is complex; note that Jehoiakim was the first king to be taken by Babylon
The term 'deportation' (verse 14) refers to the forced removal of the people from their land, which was a common practice in ancient empires but had severe consequences for the community
The phrase 'innocent blood' (verse 10) refers to the shedding of blood in the context of temple sacrifices and the sin of the nation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's judgment and the call to repentance to your life this week?
tips: Reflect on an area where you have been unrepentant in your life, like the sin of the nation (e.g., idolatry, injustice)
Pray for the heart of the exiled community and ask God to help you see your own sin and repent
Commit to one specific step of obedience that aligns with the call to repentance, such as sharing your sins with a trusted person

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: For the exiled community and for your own heart in light of this passage.
tips: Thank God for His sovereignty over the nations and His judgment on the sin of the nation
Ask for the courage to repent and the strength to endure in the exile
Pray for the promise of future restoration through Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Kings 25:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the siege and the desperation of Zedekiah's escape.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the city of Jerusalem' (v.2, v.5, v.7)
Pay attention to the desperate escape of Zedekiah: 'fled by night through the gate between the walls' (v.8)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is involved (Zedekiah, Babylon, the people of Jerusalem), WHAT happens (the siege, fall, deportation), WHERE it occurs (Jerusalem), and WHY it matters (the end of the kingdom of Judah and the hope for the Davidic line).
tips: Include the famine and breach of Jerusalem's wall (v.4-7)
Note Zedekiah's capture and execution of officials (v.8-14)
Mention Jehoiachin's release from prison (v.21-27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Zedekiah's escape (v.8-10), the execution of officials (v.13-14), or Jehoiachin's release (v.21-27)?
tips: Zedekiah's escape: 'fled by night through the gate between the walls' (v.8) shows the desperation of the city's fall
The execution of officials: 'the chief priest, second priest, three doorkeepers' (v.13) shows the complete destruction of religious authority
Jehoiachin's release: 'Evil-merodach of Babylon releases him from prison' (v.21) is a glimmer of hope for the Davidic line

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Jeremiah/editors trying to communicate to exilic Israel through this passage?
tips: This passage shows the consequences of unfaithfulness to God (Zedekiah's rebellion)
It emphasizes the hope that God preserves a remnant (Jehoiachin's release)
The temple's destruction and deportation are God's judgment, but He provides a future hope for the Davidic line

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The execution of officials? The deportation? The role of the Chaldeans?
tips: The term 'Chaldean' refers to the Babylonian army (not a nation but a military force)
Zedekiah's blinding: 'his eyes are put out' (v.12) is a severe punishment but also a symbol of his inability to see God's kingdom
The deportation of the poor: 'they break up the bronze pillars, stands, and sea' (v.11) shows the destruction of temple wealth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of hope in the midst of judgment: How can you apply this this week?
tips: When you face hardship, remember that God might be working to preserve a remnant (like Jehoiachin) for a future purpose
Ask God to show you where He is preserving a small group of people in your life
Pray for the hope that comes from God's faithfulness even in the midst of destruction

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of hope in the midst of judgment: Thank God for His preservation and ask for courage to trust Him.
tips: Thank God that He preserved Jehoiachin for a future purpose
Pray for strength to trust God when circumstances seem hopeless
Ask God to reveal how He is working in your life to preserve a remnant
